trans-unit.source: Get started with your first Azure Search application in .NET | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Get started with your first Azure Search application in .NET | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Tutorial on how to build a Visual Studio solution using the .NET client library from the Azure Search .NET SDK.
trans-unit.target: Tutorial on how to build a Visual Studio solution using the .NET client library from the Azure Search .NET SDK.

trans-unit.source: Get started with your first Azure Search application in .NET
trans-unit.target: Get started with your first Azure Search application in .NET

trans-unit.source: Learn how to build a custom .NET search application in Visual Studio 2013 or later that uses Azure Search for its search experience.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to build a custom .NET search application in Visual Studio 2013 or later that uses Azure Search for its search experience.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial uses the <link><linkText>Azure Search .NET SDK</linkText><title></title></link> to build classes for the objects and operations used in this exercise, as well as the Azure Search service REST API.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial uses the <link><linkText>Azure Search .NET SDK</linkText><title></title></link> to build classes for the objects and operations used in this exercise, as well as the Azure Search service REST API.

trans-unit.source: To run this sample, you need an Azure Search service, which you can sign up for in the <link><linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To run this sample, you need an Azure Search service, which you can sign up for in the <link><linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Download the source code for this tutorial at <link><linkText>Azure Search .NET Samples</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Download the source code for this tutorial at <link><linkText>Azure Search .NET Samples</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Learn how to set up connections and send requests in <link><linkText>How to use Azure Search from a .NET application</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to set up connections and send requests in <link><linkText>How to use Azure Search from a .NET application</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: About the data
trans-unit.target: About the data

trans-unit.source: This sample application uses data from the <link><linkText>United States Geological Services (USGS)</linkText><title></title></link>, filtered on the state of Rhode Island to reduce the dataset size.
trans-unit.target: This sample application uses data from the <link><linkText>United States Geological Services (USGS)</linkText><title></title></link>, filtered on the state of Rhode Island to reduce the dataset size.

trans-unit.source: We'll use this data to build a search application that returns landmark buildings such as hospitals and schools, as well as geological features like streams, lakes, and summits.
trans-unit.target: We'll use this data to build a search application that returns landmark buildings such as hospitals and schools, as well as geological features like streams, lakes, and summits.

trans-unit.source: In this application, the DataIndexer program builds and loads the index using an Indexer construct, retrieving the filtered USGS dataset from a public Azure SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: In this application, the DataIndexer program builds and loads the index using an Indexer construct, retrieving the filtered USGS dataset from a public Azure SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: Credentials and connection information to the online data source is provided in the program code.
trans-unit.target: Credentials and connection information to the online data source is provided in the program code.

trans-unit.source: No further configuration is necessary.
trans-unit.target: No further configuration is necessary.

trans-unit.source: We applied a filter on this dataset to stay under the 10,000 document limit of the free pricing tier.
trans-unit.target: We applied a filter on this dataset to stay under the 10,000 document limit of the free pricing tier.

trans-unit.source: If you use the standard tier, this limit does not apply.
trans-unit.target: If you use the standard tier, this limit does not apply.

trans-unit.source: For details about capacity for each pricing tier, see <link><linkText>Limits and constraints</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For details about capacity for each pricing tier, see <link><linkText>Limits and constraints</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Create the Azure Search service
trans-unit.target: Create the Azure Search service

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the <link><linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the <link><linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In the Jumpbar, click New > Data + Storage > Search.
trans-unit.target: In the Jumpbar, click New > Data + Storage > Search.

trans-unit.source: Configure the service name, pricing tier, resource group, subscription and location.
trans-unit.target: Configure the service name, pricing tier, resource group, subscription and location.

trans-unit.source: These settings are required and cannot be changed once the service is provisioned.
trans-unit.target: These settings are required and cannot be changed once the service is provisioned.

trans-unit.source: Service name must be unique, lower-case, under 15 characters, with no spaces.
trans-unit.target: Service name must be unique, lower-case, under 15 characters, with no spaces.

trans-unit.source: This name becomes part of the endpoint of your Azure Search service.
trans-unit.target: This name becomes part of the endpoint of your Azure Search service.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Naming Rules</linkText><title></title></link> for more information about naming conventions.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Naming Rules</linkText><title></title></link> for more information about naming conventions.

trans-unit.source: Pricing Tier determines capacity and billing.
trans-unit.target: Pricing Tier determines capacity and billing.

trans-unit.source: Both tiers provide the same features, but at different resource levels.
trans-unit.target: Both tiers provide the same features, but at different resource levels.

trans-unit.source: Free runs on clusters that are shared with other subscribers.
trans-unit.target: Free runs on clusters that are shared with other subscribers.

trans-unit.source: It offers enough capacity to try out tutorials and write proof-of-concept code, but is not intended for production applications.
trans-unit.target: It offers enough capacity to try out tutorials and write proof-of-concept code, but is not intended for production applications.

trans-unit.source: Deploying a free service typically only takes a few minutes.
trans-unit.target: Deploying a free service typically only takes a few minutes.

trans-unit.source: Standard runs on dedicated resources and is highly scalable.
trans-unit.target: Standard runs on dedicated resources and is highly scalable.

trans-unit.source: Initially, a standard service is provisioned with one replica and one partition, but you can adjust capacity once the service is created.
trans-unit.target: Initially, a standard service is provisioned with one replica and one partition, but you can adjust capacity once the service is created.

trans-unit.source: Deploying a standard service takes longer, usually about fifteen minutes.
trans-unit.target: Deploying a standard service takes longer, usually about fifteen minutes.

trans-unit.source: Resource Groups are containers for services and resources used for a common purpose.
trans-unit.target: Resource Groups are containers for services and resources used for a common purpose.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you're building a custom search application based on Azure Search, Azure Websites, Azure BLOB storage, you could create a resource group that keeps these services together in the portal management pages.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you're building a custom search application based on Azure Search, Azure Websites, Azure BLOB storage, you could create a resource group that keeps these services together in the portal management pages.

trans-unit.source: Subscription allows you to choose among multiple subscriptions, if you have more than one subscription.
trans-unit.target: Subscription allows you to choose among multiple subscriptions, if you have more than one subscription.

trans-unit.source: Location is the data center region.
trans-unit.target: Location is the data center region.

trans-unit.source: Currently, all resources must run in the same data center.
trans-unit.target: Currently, all resources must run in the same data center.

trans-unit.source: Distributing resources across multiple data centers is not supported.
trans-unit.target: Distributing resources across multiple data centers is not supported.

trans-unit.source: Click Create to provision the service.
trans-unit.target: Click Create to provision the service.

trans-unit.source: Watch for notifications in the Jumpbar.
trans-unit.target: Watch for notifications in the Jumpbar.

trans-unit.source: A notice will appear when the service is ready to use.
trans-unit.target: A notice will appear when the service is ready to use.

trans-unit.source: Find the service name and api-keys of your Azure Search service
trans-unit.target: Find the service name and api-keys of your Azure Search service

trans-unit.source: After you create the service, return to the portal to get the URL or api-key.
trans-unit.target: After you create the service, return to the portal to get the URL or api-key.

trans-unit.source: Connections to your Search service require that you have both the URL and an api-key to authenticate the call.
trans-unit.target: Connections to your Search service require that you have both the URL and an api-key to authenticate the call.

trans-unit.source: In the Jumpbar, click Home and then click the Search service to open the service dashboard.
trans-unit.target: In the Jumpbar, click Home and then click the Search service to open the service dashboard.

trans-unit.source: On the service dashboard, you'll see tiles for essential information, as well as the key icon for accessing the admin keys.
trans-unit.target: On the service dashboard, you'll see tiles for essential information, as well as the key icon for accessing the admin keys.

trans-unit.source: Copy the service URL and an admin key.
trans-unit.target: Copy the service URL and an admin key.

trans-unit.source: You'll need them later, when you add them to the app.config and web.config files in your Visual Studio projects.
trans-unit.target: You'll need them later, when you add them to the app.config and web.config files in your Visual Studio projects.

trans-unit.source: Start a new project and solution
trans-unit.target: Start a new project and solution

trans-unit.source: This solution includes two projects:
trans-unit.target: This solution includes two projects:

trans-unit.source: DataIndexer, a Visual C# console application, used for loading data.
trans-unit.target: DataIndexer, a Visual C# console application, used for loading data.

trans-unit.source: SimpleSearchMVCApp, a Visual C# ASP.NET MVC Web application, used to query and return search results.
trans-unit.target: SimpleSearchMVCApp, a Visual C# ASP.NET MVC Web application, used to query and return search results.

trans-unit.source: In this step, you'll create both projects.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you'll create both projects.

trans-unit.source: Start Visual Studio > New Project > Visual C# > Console Application.
trans-unit.target: Start Visual Studio > New Project > Visual C# > Console Application.

trans-unit.source: Name the project DataIndexer and then name the solution AzureSearchDotNetDemo.
trans-unit.target: Name the project DataIndexer and then name the solution AzureSearchDotNetDemo.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, on solution, right-click Add > New Project > Visual C# > ASP.NET Web Application.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, on solution, right-click Add > New Project > Visual C# > ASP.NET Web Application.

trans-unit.source: Name the project SimpleSearchMVCApp.
trans-unit.target: Name the project SimpleSearchMVCApp.

trans-unit.source: In the New ASP.NET Project, choose the MVC template, and clear options to avoid creating program artifacts that you won't be using in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: In the New ASP.NET Project, choose the MVC template, and clear options to avoid creating program artifacts that you won't be using in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Clear the checkboxes for Azure Hosting and Unit Tests, and set Authentication to none.
trans-unit.target: Clear the checkboxes for Azure Hosting and Unit Tests, and set Authentication to none.

trans-unit.source: When you're finished creating the projects, your solution should look similar to the example shown below.
trans-unit.target: When you're finished creating the projects, your solution should look similar to the example shown below.

trans-unit.source: Install the .NET client library and update other packages
trans-unit.target: Install the .NET client library and update other packages

trans-unit.source: Right-click Manage NuGet Packages on the solution in Solution Explorer.
trans-unit.target: Right-click Manage NuGet Packages on the solution in Solution Explorer.

trans-unit.source: Specify Updates > Stable Only > Update All.
trans-unit.target: Specify Updates > Stable Only > Update All.

trans-unit.source: Accept the additional package installations so that all dependencies are also installed.
trans-unit.target: Accept the additional package installations so that all dependencies are also installed.

trans-unit.source: Next, install the Azure Search .NET client library.
trans-unit.target: Next, install the Azure Search .NET client library.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to specify the search correctly or you won't easily find the package.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to specify the search correctly or you won't easily find the package.

trans-unit.source: Right-click Manage NuGet Packages again.
trans-unit.target: Right-click Manage NuGet Packages again.

trans-unit.source: Specify Online > nuget.org > Include Prerelease, and then search for azure.search.
trans-unit.target: Specify Online > nuget.org > Include Prerelease, and then search for azure.search.

trans-unit.source: Click Install to install the library.
trans-unit.target: Click Install to install the library.

trans-unit.source: A partial list of the assemblies used in this example is shown below.
trans-unit.target: A partial list of the assemblies used in this example is shown below.

trans-unit.source: Add an assembly reference for System.Configuration
trans-unit.target: Add an assembly reference for System.Configuration

trans-unit.source: DataIndexer uses System.Configuration to read the configuration settings in app.config.
trans-unit.target: DataIndexer uses System.Configuration to read the configuration settings in app.config.

trans-unit.source: Right-click DataIndexer > Add > Reference > Framework > System.Configuration.
trans-unit.target: Right-click DataIndexer > Add > Reference > Framework > System.Configuration.

trans-unit.source: Select the check box.
trans-unit.target: Select the check box.

trans-unit.source: Click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click OK.

trans-unit.source: Update configuration files
trans-unit.target: Update configuration files

trans-unit.source: Each project includes configuration files that specify the service name and api-key.
trans-unit.target: Each project includes configuration files that specify the service name and api-key.

trans-unit.source: In DataIndexer, replace App.config with the following example, updating the [SERVICE NAME] and [SERVICE KEY] with values that are valid for your service.
trans-unit.target: In DataIndexer, replace App.config with the following example, updating the [SERVICE NAME] and [SERVICE KEY] with values that are valid for your service.

trans-unit.source: Note that the service name is not the full URL.
trans-unit.target: Note that the service name is not the full URL.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your Search service endpoint is https://mysearchsrv.search.microsoft.net, the service name you would enter in App.config is mysearchsrv.
trans-unit.target: For example, if your Search service endpoint is https://mysearchsrv.search.microsoft.net, the service name you would enter in App.config is mysearchsrv.

trans-unit.source: In SimpleSearchMVCApp, replace Web.config with the following example, again updating [SERVICE NAME] and [SERVICE KEY] with values that are valid for your service.
trans-unit.target: In SimpleSearchMVCApp, replace Web.config with the following example, again updating [SERVICE NAME] and [SERVICE KEY] with values that are valid for your service.

trans-unit.source: Modify DataIndexer
trans-unit.target: Modify DataIndexer

trans-unit.source: This program is a console app that connects to your Search service as specified in app.config, creates the index, and then loads it with USGS dataset stored in an Azure SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: This program is a console app that connects to your Search service as specified in app.config, creates the index, and then loads it with USGS dataset stored in an Azure SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: Currently, the pre-release version of the client library does not support indexers, so we'll use the REST API to create and use an indexer for this portion of the tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Currently, the pre-release version of the client library does not support indexers, so we'll use the REST API to create and use an indexer for this portion of the tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Before you can run this program, you'll make two modifications:
trans-unit.target: Before you can run this program, you'll make two modifications:

trans-unit.source: Add AzureSearchhelper.cs, used when calling the REST API to handle connections and serialize and deserialize JSON requests and responses.
trans-unit.target: Add AzureSearchhelper.cs, used when calling the REST API to handle connections and serialize and deserialize JSON requests and responses.

trans-unit.source: Replace Program.cs, used to create the index, indexer, load data, and write messages.
trans-unit.target: Replace Program.cs, used to create the index, indexer, load data, and write messages.

trans-unit.source: Create AzureSearchHelper.cs
trans-unit.target: Create AzureSearchHelper.cs

trans-unit.source: Code that calls the REST API should include a class that handles connections and the serialization and deserialization of JSON requests and responses.
trans-unit.target: Code that calls the REST API should include a class that handles connections and the serialization and deserialization of JSON requests and responses.

trans-unit.source: In the samples provided with Azure Search, this class is typically called AzureSearchHelper.cs.
trans-unit.target: In the samples provided with Azure Search, this class is typically called AzureSearchHelper.cs.

trans-unit.source: You can create this class and add it to DataIndexer, using the following code.
trans-unit.target: You can create this class and add it to DataIndexer, using the following code.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click DataIndexer > Add > New Item > Code > Class.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click DataIndexer > Add > New Item > Code > Class.

trans-unit.source: Name the class AzureSearchHelper.
trans-unit.target: Name the class AzureSearchHelper.

trans-unit.source: Replace the default code with the following code.
trans-unit.target: Replace the default code with the following code.

trans-unit.source: Update Program.cs
trans-unit.target: Update Program.cs

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, open DataIndexer > Program.cs.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, open DataIndexer > Program.cs.

trans-unit.source: Replace the contents of Program.cs with the following code.
trans-unit.target: Replace the contents of Program.cs with the following code.

trans-unit.source: Build and Run DataIndexer
trans-unit.target: Build and Run DataIndexer

trans-unit.source: Right-click the DataIndexer project.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the DataIndexer project.

trans-unit.source: Build the project.
trans-unit.target: Build the project.

trans-unit.source: Press F5 to run it.
trans-unit.target: Press F5 to run it.

trans-unit.source: You should see a console window with these messages.
trans-unit.target: You should see a console window with these messages.

trans-unit.source: In the portal, you should see a new geonames index.
trans-unit.target: In the portal, you should see a new geonames index.

trans-unit.source: It can take the portal several minutes to catch up, so you might want to wait a bit before checking the results.
trans-unit.target: It can take the portal several minutes to catch up, so you might want to wait a bit before checking the results.

trans-unit.source: Modify SimpleSearchMVCApp
trans-unit.target: Modify SimpleSearchMVCApp

trans-unit.source: SimpleSearchMVC is a web app that runs locally in IIS Express.
trans-unit.target: SimpleSearchMVC is a web app that runs locally in IIS Express.

trans-unit.source: It provides a search box and presents search results in a table.
trans-unit.target: It provides a search box and presents search results in a table.

trans-unit.source: Before you can run this program, you'll make three modifications:
trans-unit.target: Before you can run this program, you'll make three modifications:

trans-unit.source: Replace HomeController.cs, used to accept user input.
trans-unit.target: Replace HomeController.cs, used to accept user input.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the search term is stored in a variable named q.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the search term is stored in a variable named q.

trans-unit.source: Replace index.cshtml, a web page that provides the search term inputs and displays search results.
trans-unit.target: Replace index.cshtml, a web page that provides the search term inputs and displays search results.

trans-unit.source: Add FeatureSearch.cs, a class that creates the search client and executes the search.
trans-unit.target: Add FeatureSearch.cs, a class that creates the search client and executes the search.

trans-unit.source: Update HomeController.cs
trans-unit.target: Update HomeController.cs

trans-unit.source: Replace the default code with the following code.
trans-unit.target: Replace the default code with the following code.

trans-unit.source: Update Index.cshtml
trans-unit.target: Update Index.cshtml

trans-unit.source: Replace the default code with the following code.
trans-unit.target: Replace the default code with the following code.

trans-unit.source: Add FeaturesSearch.cs
trans-unit.target: Add FeaturesSearch.cs

trans-unit.source: Add a class that provides search functionality to your application.
trans-unit.target: Add a class that provides search functionality to your application.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click SimpleSearchMVCApp > Add > New Item > Code > Class.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click SimpleSearchMVCApp > Add > New Item > Code > Class.

trans-unit.source: Name the class FeaturesSearch.
trans-unit.target: Name the class FeaturesSearch.

trans-unit.source: Replace the default code with the following code.
trans-unit.target: Replace the default code with the following code.

trans-unit.source: Set SimpleSearchMVCApp as the start-up project
trans-unit.target: Set SimpleSearchMVCApp as the start-up project

trans-unit.source: Right-click the SimpleSearchMVCApp project to set it as the start-up project.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the SimpleSearchMVCApp project to set it as the start-up project.

trans-unit.source: Build and run SimpleSearchMVCApp
trans-unit.target: Build and run SimpleSearchMVCApp

trans-unit.source: When you build and run this program, you should see a web page in your default browser, providing a search box for accessing USGS data stored in the index in your Azure Search service.
trans-unit.target: When you build and run this program, you should see a web page in your default browser, providing a search box for accessing USGS data stored in the index in your Azure Search service.

trans-unit.source: Search on USGS data
trans-unit.target: Search on USGS data

trans-unit.source: The USGS data set includes records that are relevant to the state of Rhode Island.
trans-unit.target: The USGS data set includes records that are relevant to the state of Rhode Island.

trans-unit.source: If you click Search on an empty search box, you will get the top 50 entries, which is the default.
trans-unit.target: If you click Search on an empty search box, you will get the top 50 entries, which is the default.

trans-unit.source: Entering a search term will give the search engine criteria for narrowing the search.
trans-unit.target: Entering a search term will give the search engine criteria for narrowing the search.

trans-unit.source: Try entering a regional name.
trans-unit.target: Try entering a regional name.

trans-unit.source: Roger Williams was the first governor of Rhode Island.
trans-unit.target: Roger Williams was the first governor of Rhode Island.

trans-unit.source: Numerous parks, buildings, and schools are named after him.
trans-unit.target: Numerous parks, buildings, and schools are named after him.

trans-unit.source: You could also try these queries, adding or removing phrases or operators to re-scope your search:
trans-unit.target: You could also try these queries, adding or removing phrases or operators to re-scope your search:

trans-unit.source: Pawtucket OR Pembroke
trans-unit.target: Pawtucket OR Pembroke

trans-unit.source: goose +cape -neck
trans-unit.target: goose +cape -neck

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: This is the first Azure Search tutorial based on .NET and the USGS dataset.
trans-unit.target: This is the first Azure Search tutorial based on .NET and the USGS dataset.

trans-unit.source: Over time, we'll extend this tutorial to demonstrate additional search features you might want to use in your custom solutions.
trans-unit.target: Over time, we'll extend this tutorial to demonstrate additional search features you might want to use in your custom solutions.

trans-unit.source: If you already have some background in Azure Search, you can use this sample as a springboard for trying suggesters (type-ahead or autocomplete queries), filters, and faceted navigation.
trans-unit.target: If you already have some background in Azure Search, you can use this sample as a springboard for trying suggesters (type-ahead or autocomplete queries), filters, and faceted navigation.

trans-unit.source: You can also improve upon the search results page by adding counts and batching documents so that users can page through the results.
trans-unit.target: You can also improve upon the search results page by adding counts and batching documents so that users can page through the results.

trans-unit.source: New to Azure Search?
trans-unit.target: New to Azure Search?

trans-unit.source: We recommend trying other tutorials to develop an understanding of what you can create.
trans-unit.target: We recommend trying other tutorials to develop an understanding of what you can create.

trans-unit.source: Visit our <link><linkText>documentation page</linkText><title></title></link> to find more resources.
trans-unit.target: Visit our <link><linkText>documentation page</linkText><title></title></link> to find more resources.

trans-unit.source: You can also view the links in our <link><linkText>Video and Tutorial list</linkText><title></title></link> to access more information.
trans-unit.target: You can also view the links in our <link><linkText>Video and Tutorial list</linkText><title></title></link> to access more information.
